abstract_problem: This instance describes dispatch planning for short-haul container moves around a terminal and its nearby transfer points. There are {N} transport orders and {M} available chassis. The planner must decide a one-to-one pairing so that every order is covered and every chassis is used exactly once. Pairing is allowed for any order-chassis combination; the data provide explicit cost entries for some pairings and all other pairings use an implicit baseline cost of {baseline_assignment_cost}. The plan also tracks {num_time_vars} event timestamps for key visits or handoffs. Operational policies are given as standardized rule records that link pairing choices to timing consistency requirements and to shared-facility limits aggregated over specific order groups (groups may cover only a subset of orders). In this instance, each order has a designated primary chassis option that shares the same identifier as the order, and timing-shift rules describe how the required time gap changes when switching from that primary option to an alternative. Each rule table uses a uniform comparison direction code, given by {pair_time_link_default_sense} for timing-shift rules and {chassis_time_default_sense} for group-aggregation rules. Timing-shift rules also rely on a shared large adjustment constant {pair_time_link_big_m}. All identifiers in the data files are zero-based. The goal is to find a feasible plan with minimum total cost.

assignment_costs.description: Cost entries associated with pairing an order and a chassis. The pairing decision is allowed for any order-chassis combination; this file only lists the pairings that have an explicit (non-baseline) cost entry. Any pairing not listed should be treated as having the baseline (implicit) cost contribution. Identifiers are zero-based integers. Data format: | order_id | chassis_id | cost |\n| <int> | <int> | <float> |

time_bounds.description: Allowed ranges for event timestamps. Each row provides a lower and upper limit for one timestamp identifier. Identifiers are zero-based integers. Data format: | time_id | lower_bound | upper_bound |\n| <int> | <float> | <float> |

pair_time_link_rules.description: Rule records that connect an order's chassis choice to the allowed time gap between two event timestamps. Each row references one order, one alternative chassis option for that order, and two timestamps, and it encodes a single linear rule template that shifts the required time gap depending on whether the order keeps its designated primary chassis or switches to the alternative. The designated primary chassis for an order is the chassis with the same identifier as the order. The rule uses the one-to-one assignment indicators for (order_id, primary_chassis) and (order_id, chassis_alternative). The comparison direction and the large adjustment constant are uniform across all rows and are provided in `problem_structure.csv`. The implemented rule template is: (time_to - time_from) + fixed_choice_coefficient * assign(order_id, primary_chassis) - (large_adjustment_constant) * assign(order_id, chassis_alternative) (comparison_direction) rhs. Identifiers are zero-based integers. Data format: | rhs | order_id | chassis_alternative | time_from | time_to | fixed_choice_coefficient |\n| <float> | <int> | <int> | <int> | <int> | <float> |

chassis_time_rules.description: Aggregate rule records that connect how a specific chassis is used across a referenced set of orders with one event timestamp. The affected set of orders is provided by `order_groups.csv`. The comparison direction and the right-hand-side threshold are uniform across all rows and are provided in `problem_structure.csv`. The implemented rule template is: time(time_id) + assignment_coefficient * sum_{order in order_groups.csv} assign(order, chassis_id) (comparison_direction) (threshold). Identifiers are zero-based integers. Data format: | chassis_id | time_id | assignment_coefficient |\n| <int> | <int> | <float> |

order_groups.description: Orders referenced by the aggregate rules in `chassis_time_rules.csv`. Each row lists one order identifier that belongs to the single aggregate set used by this instance (the set may cover only a subset of all orders). Identifiers are zero-based integers. Data format: | order_id |\n| <int> |

problem_structure.description: Instance-level scalar metadata for driving loops and sanity checks without hard-coding dimensions. This file provides the key instance dimensions referenced in the narrative (such as the number of orders, chassis, and timestamps) as well as the uniform default constants used by the rule tables (baseline cost, comparison direction codes, shared adjustment constant, and shared thresholds). Data format: | parameter | value |\n| <string> | <string> |
